title: Thales's theorem
summary: In geometry, Thales's theorem states that if A, B, and C are distinct points on a circle where the line AC is a diameter, the angle âˆ  ABC is a right angle. Thales's theorem is a special case of the inscribed angle theorem and is mentioned and proved as part of the 31st proposition in the third book of Euclid's Elements.[1] It is generally attributed to Thales of Miletus, but it is sometimes attributed to Pythagoras.
